> So is your idea mainly to coevolve DNA "starter strings" in one
> population and "rule sets" (or something analogous) in another?

Right. At the outset, DNA will be small, rule sets will be small, and they
would complexify incrementally.

> If that's it, I take it the main innovation here is not always
> starting from a single canonical symbol?  It does sound interesting.

The resulting phenotype, probably, will still start out as one "cell" or
whatever is analogous in NNs. Then the developmental system will read
through the genetic information in that cell, interpret it according to
its rules, and perform whatever operations, until the end of the
development phase.

I haven't really worked any of this out, its just an idea floating around
my notes.

The interesting aspect, I think, is the decoupling of the "hardware" for
development (embryogenic system), and the "software" (genetic data).
Most of the work I've looked at has the developmental system encoded
in the genetic information and applied to a basic phenotype.

Though truly this really can't be called an innovation since biology has
been doing it much longer than I have.

-- 

Joseph Reisinger
